questions.question: On watching the documentary 'The Secret of Our Lives: The Human Genome Project', astudent reads up about the international consortium of scientists who fully deciphered theDNA of the most common chromosomal syndrome. What is this syndrome?
A 39-year-old pregnant woman was found to have an abnormal nuchal translucency scan. Anamniocentesis done revealed a chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21. This result mostcommonly occurs due to?
questions.explanation: The chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21 is suggestive of Down's syndrome which occurs due tonondisjunction in maternal meiosis. Non-disjunction points to the failure of the homologouschromosome to separate during the meiotic division.Down's syndrome:• Most common chromosomal disorder•• Incidence: 1/800 live births• Mechanism:•Trisomy 21 (meiotic maternal nondisjunction) (95%)• Robertsonian translocation: 4%• Mosaic pattern: 1%Note:• Robertsonian translocations: involve 2 acrocentric chromosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21,and 22) that fuse near the centromeric region, with a subsequent loss of the short arms.malefemalemiscarriagechromosome 13chromosome 21Robertsonian translocationder(13;21)(q10;q10)CarrierNormalDown syndromeCarrierDown syndrome Normal

questions.question: Your aunt has sent you an image of her 1-year-old son's palm using an instant messaging app.She read online that it is mostly present in genetic disorders and wishes to get your opinion.You identify it as a simian crease and prepare a list of differentials. All of the followingdiagnoses are correct except:213
questions.explanation: Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis.Simian crease is seen in the following disorders:Down's syndrome•⚫ Fetal alcohol syndrome224•Trisomy 13• Cri du chat syndrome

questions.question: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she isnoted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes withepicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most commonlesion expected in this syndrome?
questions.explanation: The girl is suffering from Down's syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion isan endocardial cushion defect.Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patentductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)• Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly• Congenital heart disease.•Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of theduodenum• Protruding tongue• Round face•⚫ Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth• Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots• Low (depressed) nasal bridgeEpicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic•Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)• Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toesNote:.• The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenalatresia (double-bubble sign).•Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, includingacute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML).AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.• The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia.• The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormalmyelopoiesis (TAM).• Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.Image: A child having features of Down's syndrome225Image: Brushfield's spots

questions.question: A 41-year-old entrepreneur is excited to start her family. She has been getting a lot ofunsolicited advice about the complications of pregnancy in advanced maternal age. Onenquiring about such pregnancies, the doctor advised the mother to get prenatal testing done.All are findings associated with the prenatal diagnosis for Down's syndrome except214

options.D: Ventricular septal defect may be present

questions.explanation: Increased umbilical flow is not seen during the prenatal screening for Down's syndrome, instead,the flow is decreased.Reduced blood flow through the umbilical vessels and abnormal blood flow through ductusvenosus (DV) in the first trimester are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especiallyDown's syndrome. This decrease in blood flow causes IUGR in infants born with Down syndrome.

questions.question: An elderly primigravida underwent a nuchal translucency scan at 14 weeks which was highlysuggestive of Down's syndrome. The doctor advised her to undergo a triple test and called herback at week 16. On receiving her receipt for the payment of the test, she realises that she hasbeen billed wrongly for a component that is not included in the triple test. What is thiscomponent?
questions.explanation: 226Inhibin A is not included in the triple test:Note:• AFP: Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein• HCG: Beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin• PAPPA: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A•• UE3: Unconjugated estriolTestTriple testQuadruple testCombined test(first-trimesterscreening)ComponentsAFP + hCG + UE3Triple test+Inhibin APAPPA + hCG + nuchal translucencyIntegrated test(most sensitive) Combined test + Quadruple test

questions.question: While writing your medical competitive exams, you come across the following image ofkaryotyping analysis in a question. You recognize this image as being highly suggestive of aparticular syndrome. What is the diagnosis?1 2 3 4 5 6 7 89 10 11 12 13 14 151617 18 19 20 21 22XXXY
questions.explanation: The above karyotype is suggestive of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).Clinical features of Trisomy 13/Patau syndrome (Mnemonic CMC DOCTOR OPD)•Cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect/atrial septal defect/patent ductus arteriosus)• Microcephaly, Microphthalmia• Cleft lip/palateDevelopmental delay• Ocular hypotelorism•Holoprosencephaly• Thin posterior ribs (missing ribs)• Renal abnormalities• Polydactyly with flexed fingers•Polycystic kidneys•Scalp defects (aplasia cutis)Image: 37-week male with Patau syndrome demonstrating alobar holoprosencephaly withcyclopia. Facial features included a sloping forehead with a nose superior to a single centralpalpebral fissure.227A

questions.question: A 10-month-old boy presented with facial dysmorphism as well as two characteristic findingsshown in the picture below. What is the condition affecting this newborn?
questions.explanation: The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, androcker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18).Clinical features of Edward's syndrome: (Remember mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS)•••HypertoniaMicrocephaly/MicrognathiaEighteen trisomy/Elongated skull• Digit overlapping with a closed fist• Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes• Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis• Rocker bottom feet• Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) andkidney, death.• Small lower jaw (Micrognathia), short sternum, small nipplesNote: P, Patau syndrome: Trisomy 13E, Edward's syndrome: Trisomy 18D, Down syndrome: Trisomy 21Alagille syndrome (AS) is an autosomal-dominant disorder associated with abnormalities of theliver (hypoplasia of hepatic duct), heart (tetralogy of Fallot), skeleton, eye, and kidneys and acharacteristic facial appearance.William's syndrome is a developmental disorder that is characterized by mild to moderateintellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial228features, and cardiovascular problems.

questions.question: A young girl presents to you with learning disabilities. On examination, you notice acharacteristic finding as shown in the picture below. Reports of her investigation scansmention horseshoe kidneys and streak gonads. What is your diagnosis?216
questions.explanation: The child shows characteristic webbed neck, learning disabilities, horseshoe kidneys, and streakgonads and is diagnosed with Turner's syndrome.Turner's syndrome:•••Karyotype, 45; XO, phenotypically femalesChromosomal abnormality XO is present in 60% of individuals, mosaic pattern in 40%• Intelligence remains normalImportant features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here)•Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest• Amenorrhea (primary), infertility•• Barr body absent• Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema• L: Learning disabilities• Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosomematerial is present)• Webbed neck•Nipples widely spacedHorseshoe kidneysNote:The most common cardiac defect in Turner's is bicuspid aortic valve > coarctation of aorta.

questions.question: Kaveri recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxiousand wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally.Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with anabsent Barr body?
questions.explanation: Barr body is absent in female having 45 Xo genome.Barr body•Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a femaleis found in the nucleus.• Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomeswhich become inactivated.• The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.229Note:•⚫ Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, theother becomes inactive during embryogenesis.• Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found inneutrophils of females.

questions.question: A 15-year-old adolescent presents with an anti-mongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, shortstature, webbed neck, and undescended testis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The adolescent presenting with antimongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbedneck, and undescended testis is suggestive of Noonan syndrome. Although the webbed neck is afeature of Turner syndrome as well, the likely diagnosis would be Noonan syndrome since thepatient is male (undescended testis).Noonan syndrome:• Autosomal-dominant disorder (12q)•Male or female with Turner phenotype; normal karyotype.Clinical features:•⚫ Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)• Pectus carinatum• Hypertelorism•Cryptorchidism• Low levels of clotting factor 11 and 12•Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)• Moderate mental retardation in 25%• Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis.•Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy• Atrial Septal Defect• Coarctation of aorta• Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus: similarities with Turner syndrome• Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.Difference between Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome:Noonan syndromeNormal karyotype(46XX/46XY)Most common heart disease:Valvular pulmonary stenosis25% have mental retardationTurner syndrome45, X0(60%)Most common heart disease:Bicuspid aortic valveMental retardation rare230Noonan syndromeGenitourinary:Female: Fertile, delayed pubertyMale: Infertile due to cryptorchidismTurner syndromeGenitourinary:Female: Infertile, streak ovariesNo males

questions.question: A concerned pregnant woman underwent karyotyping which was highly suggestive of aparticular syndrome. The image of her results is shown below. Which of the followingabnormalities is associated with patients with the given karyotype?2223988223186700812203DAZE6101112131415161718BB240192021
questions.explanation: 2139882671180204111314GHOTE819BB202024515DAZE211425101011121617182222The above karyotype - 47, XXY, is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome, in which gynecomastiaand long thin limbs are seen.Klinefelter's syndrome:•Most common sex aneuploidy in males• Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; ormosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY• Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division)Clinical features:⚫ Disproportionately long arms and legs• Mitral valve prolapse• Minor developmental and learning disabilities• Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)•Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80•Gynecomastia•Higher risk of breast carcinoma•Testicular dysgenesis231• Infertility/ azoospermiaNote:A variant of Klinefelter's syndrome-49, XXXXY—presents with short stature.

questions.question: A newborn with previously diagnosed Cri-du-chat syndrome presented to the hospital. Whichof the following is not observed in this condition?
questions.explanation: Hypotonia is seen in cri-du-chat syndrome, not hypertonia.Cri-du-chat syndrome occurs due to the deletion of chromosome 5p.Main features:•⚫ Hypotonia•Characteristic shrill cry (cat-like cry) in the first few weeks of life• Microcephaly• Hypertelorism• Bilateral epicanthic folds• High-arched palate• Wide and flat nasal bridge••Intellectual disabilityNote:• Cat-bite infection is caused by Pasteurella multocida.•• Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies.

questions.question: 218A senior asks you to read about an autosomal dominant condition known as Treacher- Collinssyndrome. While browsing through numerous journals to learn about the topic, you comeacross a doubt about its features. Which of the following is not associated with thissyndrome?
questions.explanation: Intelligence is not affected in Treacher-Collins syndrome (like in Turners syndrome).Treacher-Collins syndrome/Franceschetti syndrome• Autosomal dominant• Facial appearance: downward sloping palpebral fissures, colobomas and drooping of the lowereyelids, sunken cheekbones, deformed pinnae, atypical hair growth extending towards cheeks• Facial clefts, malformed ears, deafness• Hypoplastic mandibleImage: Treacher-Collins syndrome; note the sunken cheekbones, abnormality of ears, andhypoplastic mandible232

questions.question: All of the following are seen in a 5-month-old child with Pierre- Robin syndrome except?
questions.explanation: Coloboma iris is not a feature of Pierre-Robin syndrome.Features of Pierre-Robin syndrome-••Micrognathia accompanied by a high-arched or cleft palateTongue normal size; the floor of the mouth is foreshortened• Retrognathia: retracted mandible•Glossoptosis/Retroglossoptosis: tongue appears to fall into the throat (retraction of the tongue)Of the children with Pierre-Robin syndrome, 30-50% have Stickler syndrome. Featuresinclude prominent joints, arthritis, hypotonia, hypermobile joints, mitral valve prolapse, hearingloss, and ocular problems (myopia, glaucoma, cataracts, retinal detachment).Pierre-Robin syndrome as shown in the image below:233P's

questions.question: Shantanu, an avid reader, and a first-year resident, recently finished Joseph Heller's famousnovel 'Catch-22'. While discussing the book with his friend, he realized that the title was anacronym of a chromosomal disorder they had studied. Which of the following is the leastlikely feature of this disorder?
questions.explanation: DiGeorge syndrome, also known as Catch-22 syndrome, is associated with cardiac anomalies andnot cranial anomalies.DiGeorge/Shprintzen Velocardiofacial syndrome - Remember the mnemonic CATCH 22• C: Cardiac anomalies• A: Abnormal facies⚫T: Thymic aplasia and agenesis of parathyroid glands.• C: Cleft palate• H: Hypocalcemia, hypoplasia of auricle• 22: 22q11.2 deletion

questions.question: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span toheight ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, andlong slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is providedbelow. What other complications can be expected in this child?219
questions.explanation: The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is aknown complication.Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth fingeraround the wrist.Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closedfistFeatures of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN'S)•Mitral valve prolapse•Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)234• Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation• Retinal detachment• Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity•Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)•Flat feet• Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)•Nearsightedness• Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apneaThe image given below shows the Steinberg (thumb) sign:Steinberg thumb signNormalSteinberg thumb signThumb tip extending beyondthe ulnar border of the handwhen folded.OMARROW

questions.question: Venkatesh decided to present a rare case report of maternal disomy of chromosome 15 at ascientific conference. He collected the following image representing the disorder's features.What is this disorder?
questions.explanation: Maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen in Prader-Willi syndrome. The image shows thecharacteristic features of truncal obesity, short stature, and small hands and feet.Uniparental disomy: Offspring receives both copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copiesfrom the other parent.Chromosome 15 diseases: Chromosome 15 has its own MAP (mnemonic),• M: Marfan syndrome• A: Angelman syndrome•• P: Prader Willi syndromePrader-Willi syndromeAngelMan syndromeDeletionPaternal chromosome 15Maternal chromosome 15235Uniparental DisomyClinical featuresPrader-Willi syndromeAngelMan syndromeMaternal disomy(duplication) Paternal disomy (duplication)seen in 25% of casesElevated Ghrelinlevels: Lossof appetite control, obesitySevere hypotoniaShort statureSmall hands and feetHypogonadotropic hypogonadismCognitive impairmentseen in 5% of casesShort statureSevere mental retardation with lack of speechStiff arm movementsSpastic,uncoordinated walkSeizuresAn inappropriate outburst oflaughter (Happy puppets)

questions.question: Triangular facies is indicative of which of the following diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Triangular facies is indicative of Russell-Silver syndrome.•Russell-Silver syndrome:Clinical features: Short stature, triangular face (small jaw and pointed chin), microcephaly, limband facial asymmetry, 5th finger clinodactyly.• A few cases are due to genomic imprinting disorder involving chromosome 11.Note: Triangular facies is also seen in Alagille syndrome.The image given below shows a child with Russell-Silver syndrome.

questions.question: During an intersectoral collaborative event, an award-winning geneticist from the NationalHuman Genome Research Institute is invited for an endowment oration. He presents hislecture on an experimental form of treatment that uses the transfer of genetic material to curediseases known as 'Gene Therapy'. Which of the following techniques does he mention forthis therapy?
questions.explanation: Electroporation is used in gene therapy.Gene therapy is a technique that uses genes to treat or prevent disease through the delivery ofDNA into a patient's cell by using recombinant viruses/naked DNA/DNA complexes. The methods236used include intranuclear injection, electroporation, gene-gun, sonoporation, and magnetofection.Gene therapy was first used for severe combined immunodeficiency disorder (SCID), which is dueto adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency.

questions.question: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developingnormally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding?221

options.B: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
options.D: Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities

questions.explanation: The picture depicts a Simian crease - a single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal findingin about 3% of the population. In a child with simian crease and normal growth anddevelopment, reassurance should be provided.• A simian crease is one of the findings of Down's syndrome however presence of only this findingshould not lead to a diagnosis of Down's syndrome.•Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However,maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition.• Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.

questions.question: Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) is particularly useful in the modern era of diagnosisin clinical genetics. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this test?

options.B: Evaluates maternal blood for fetal abnormalities
options.D: Positive test need confirmation by invasive testing

questions.explanation: Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) has a high negative predictive value.NIPS:• Useful in screening high-risk pregnancies for aneuploidies.• Done after 10 weeks of gestation.• Evaluates maternal blood for screening.• Positive tests need confirmation by invasive testing (like amniocentesis, chorionic villoussampling).237
